newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - May 6.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - May 6.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories on Tuesday:

* In a closely watched wrongful death lawsuit in Florida, a jury ruled in favor of RJ Reynolds Tobacco, clearing the cigarette maker of responsibility for the death of a smoker who died of lung cancer.
* James River announced plans to acquire Fort Howard for $3.6 billion, forming the largest U.S. maker of tissues, paper towels and napkins.
* Swedish investment firm Incentive AB, a holding company controlled by the Wallenberg family, agreed to purchase Vivra for $1.59 billion.
* Pilots at AMR Corp's American Airlines approved a five-year contract by a wide margin.
* The U.S. Food and Drug Administration said it would not approve a generic version of Premarin, American Home Products' estrogen replacement therapy drug.
* Northrop Grumman announced plans to buy military information technology company Logicon in a $750 million stock swap.
* The Dow Jones industrial average rallied 143.29 points to close at 7,214.49.
* America Online posted a return to profitability in the most recent quarter, surprising analysts.
* A Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette unit said it would buy 85 percent of Decision One Holdings for about $660 million.
* Some business telephone customers expressed unhappiness with the U.S. Federal Communications Commission's plan to deregulate the telephone industry, saying they lose out.
* Ford said its sales declined 4.3 percent in April.
* There are reports on the Internet that Intel's Pentium II chip, due to be released on Wednesday, contains a bug that causes it to make errors in some complex mathematical calculations.
* German software firm SAP AG is being investigated by prosecutors for suspected insider trading.
* Circulation continued to decline at most large metropolitan daily newspapers.
* NBC's business news cable channel CNBC will change its prime-time schedule to better compete with Time Warner's Cable News Network.

* Market place: Bre-X Minerals gold mining scam, in which a much-touted find was exposed to contain insignificant amounts of the precious metal, evokes memories of previous stock market frauds in Canada.
* Recent findings which showed Bre-X Minerals' Busang site in Indonesia contained insignificant amounts of gold will likely erase any remaining value in the firm's shares.
